answer_variants.answer: Requirements engineering is the process of finding out exactly what a customer wants, writing it down, and moving it into a plan that the developers can actually build.

Requirements engineering is the systematic process of discovering, documenting, and managing the requirements for a software system. It bridges the gap between the informal needs of users and the formal technical specs needed by engineering.

It involves a cycle of four main tasks: 1. Elicitation (gathering), 2. Specification (writing), 3. Analysis (checking), and 4. Validation (confirming). It ensures that the software satisfies the defined constraints and business objectives.
Describe the four main phases of the requirements engineering process and the importance of the traceability matrix.

It's like 'Taking an Order at a fancy restaurant'. The waiter doesn't just say 'Okay'. They ask 'How do you want the steak cooked?', 'Any allergies?', 'What time do you need it?'. If the waiter gets the order wrong, the chef (Developer) will cook the wrong meal, no matter how good they are.
The process of defining and documenting the requirements that a software system must satisfy.

The 'Engineering' part is key. It's not just 'talking'; it's about resolving conflicts between different users, estimating the cost of each 'want', and prioritizing features based on the budget. It often ends with a 'Software Requirements Specification' (SRS) document.
Ask the user what they want, make sure it's possible, and write a checklist so you don't forget anything!

In Agile, requirements are never 'done'. We use Backlog Refinement to constantly re-evaluate requirements. We also distinguish between 'Functional Requirements' (what it does) and 'Non-functional Requirements' (how it performs/behaves).
The branch of software engineering concerned with the real-world goals for, functions of, and constraints on software systems.

questions.question: What is the difference between Functional and Non-Functional Requirements?

answer_variants.answer: Functional requirements are about 'What the app does' (like 'Log in' or 'Send Message'). Non-functional requirements are about 'How the app feels' (like 'Must load in 1 second' or 'Must be secure').

Functional requirements define the specific actions the system should be able to perform. Non-functional requirements (often called Quality Attributes) define the system's operational constraints, such as performance, scalability, security, and usability.

Functional requirements represent 'Inputs to Outputs' transformations. Non-functional requirements (NFRs) represent the 'ILITIES' (Reliability, Scalability, Portability). If a functional requirement is 'The user can pay', the NFR is 'The payment must happen within 200ms and be encrypted'.
Provide three examples each for functional and non-functional requirements for an E-commerce website.
For a 'Coffee Maker': Functional = It makes coffee. Non-Functional = The coffee must be hot, it must be ready in 2 minutes, and it shouldn't catch fire (Safety).
Functional is about behavior; Non-functional is about quality and constraints.

A system can have 100% of its functional requirements met but still be unusable. If a banking app successfully transfers money (Functional) but takes 2 hours for the screen to refresh and leaks your password (Non-functional), the software is a complete failure.
One is 'What' it does, the other is 'How well' it does it!

NFRs are harder to test because they are often global. You can check a 'Login' button in one minute, but checking if a site can handle 10,000 users (Scalability) requires a high-level environment and expensive load-testing tools.
Functional requirements define what a system is supposed to do; Non-functional requirements define how the system is supposed to be.
A user story is a simple sentence that describes what a specific person wants to do in the app and why it helps them.
A user story is an informal, natural language description of one or more features of a software system. It typically follows the format: 'As a [user], I want to [action], so that [benefit]'.

User stories are the primary unit of work in Agile/Scrum. They focus on 'The Value' rather than the 'Implementation'. A good user story follows the INVEST criteria: Independent, Negotiable, Valuable, Estimable, Small, and Testable.
Write a user story for a 'Password Reset' feature following the standard template.

It's like 'A Post-it Note on a fridge'. It's not a 10-page grocery list; it's just a reminder: 'We need eggs so we can make breakfast tomorrow'. It's a conversation starter for the family (the team) to decide what kind of eggs to buy.
A short, simple description of a feature told from the perspective of the person who desires the new capability.

User stories include 'Acceptance Criteria'. This is a list of 'Checks' that must pass before the story is considered 'Done'. For example: 'Must send email within 5 seconds' or 'User must be logged out after reset'. Without AC, the developer might finish the code but fail to meet the user's actual need.
A way to explain what a feature should do in plain English so everyone (even non-techies) can understand it!

The mistake teams make is 'Splitting stories by technology' (e.g., 'Make DB table'). A true user story must be a 'Vertical Slice' of the whole system—it should result in something a user can actually see or use once it's finished.
A tool used in Agile software development to capture a description of a software feature from an end-user perspective.
Elicitation is just 'Asking Questions' to find out what the user really needs, using interviews, surveys, or watching them work.

Elicitation is the practice of gathering requirements from stakeholders. It's often difficult because users may not know what they want, may have trouble expressing it, or may have conflicting ideas with other users.

Techniques for elicitation include: Interviews, Surveys/Questionnaires, Observation (Ethnography), Document Analysis, and JAD (Joint Application Development) sessions. It is the 'Discovery' phase of Requirements Engineering.
Compare 'Interviews' and 'Surveys' as requirements elicitation techniques in terms of depth and breadth.

It's like 'Being a Detective'. You don't just ask the witness 'Who did it?'. You look at clues, ask about the weather, see who was in the room, and slowly piece together the story of 'The Right Software' that needs to be built.
The process of discovering and collecting requirements for a system from stakeholders.

Often, the 'Requirement' you get isn't the 'Need'. A user might say 'I want a big red button' (Requirement). Through elicitation, you find out they actually 'Need to stop the machine quickly'. You might decide an 'Emergency Lever' is better. Good elicitation finds the 'Why' behind the 'What'.
The art of being a good listener and asking the right questions to find out what to build!

For expert systems, we use 'Task Analysis' where we record every single click and keystroke a user currently takes to perform a job. We then redesign the software to eliminate 80% of those steps, proving the value of the software before it's even built.
The research and discovery of the requirements of a system from users, customers and other stakeholders.
The SRS is the 'Final Recipe' for the software. It's a document that explains every button, every screen, and every rule the app must follow.

The Software Requirements Specification is a technical document that defines what the software is expected to do. It serves as a contract between the client and the developer, ensuring both parties have the same expectations before coding begins.

A standard SRS includes: 1. Introduction, 2. Overall Description, 3. Specific Requirements (Functional/Non-functional), 4. Interface Requirements (UI/API), 5. Design Constraints. It should be Unambiguous, Complete, Consistent, and Verifiable.
List the typical contents of a Software Requirements Specification (SRS) document according to IEEE 830 standards.
It's like 'The Blueprints for a House'. It shows where the walls are, how thick the glass is, and where the wires go. The builders don't have to guess; they just follow the drawing.
A complete description of the behavior and constraints of a software system to be developed.

Writing an SRS correctly is hard. If you say 'The system must be fast,' that's useless (unverifiable). You must say 'The system must respond to search within 500ms for up to 1000 concurrent users.' An SRS is the source of truth for the QA team to write their test cases.
The official 'rulebook' for your app! It’s the final version of the plan that everyone agrees on.

In 'Lean' development, the SRS is often replaced by a shared digital 'Living' document (like Jira or a Wiki). This ensures the spec is always up-to-date with reality, rather than a frozen PDF that becomes obsolete the moment coding starts.
A formal document that describes the functions and performance of a software-based system and the constraints that will affect its development.
A feasibility study is asking: 'Can we actually do this?' It checks if the app is too expensive, too hard to build, or if it will actually make money.

A feasibility study is a preliminary assessment of a project. We look at Technical Feasibility (can we build it?), Economic Feasibility (is it worth it?), and Operational Feasibility (will the users accept it?).

It evaluates: 1. Technical (Stack complexity), 2. Economic (ROI/CBA), 3. Legal (Compliance), 4. Operational (Workflows), 5. Schedule (Deadlines). It determines if the project should proceed to the next phase.
Differentiate between Technical and Economic feasibility with examples for a new AI project.

It's like 'Planning a Trip to Mars'. Technical: Can we build a rocket? Economic: Do we have enough money? Legal: Are we allowed to park there? If the answer to any of these is 'No', you don't start building the rocket.
An assessment of the practicality and viability of a proposed software project.

The result of a feasibility study is a recommendation: 'Go', 'No-Go', or 'Go with changes'. Often, companies find that buying an existing piece of software is more feasible than building a custom one from scratch (Build vs. Buy decision).
The 'reality check' you do before you start spending a lot of time and money on a cool idea!

Strategic Feasibility is often overlooked. A project might be technically and economically feasible, but if it doesn't align with the company's long-term brand (e.g., a luxury brand building a cheap, buggy app), it should still be rejected.
A preliminary analysis that identifies the most likely possibilities and helps in determining the success or failure of a project idea.
UML is a set of 'Drawing Rules' for developers. Instead of writing 100 pages of text, you Draw pictures (diagrams) to show how the different parts of the code talk to each other.

UML is a standardized modeling language used to visualize the design of a system. It includes Structural diagrams (like Class Diagrams) and Behavioral diagrams (like Use Case or Sequence Diagrams) to help teams communicate architecturally.

UML provides a bridge between analysis and design. Common diagrams include: Class (Static), Sequence (Dynamic), State (Lifecycle), and Use Case (Functional). It ensures that complex object-oriented designs are documented consistently.
Name three different UML diagrams and state whether each is 'Structural' or 'Behavioral'.

It's like 'Music Notation'. Musicians from 10 different countries can read the same sheet music and play the same song perfectly. UML lets developers from 10 different countries read one drawing and understand exactly how the code works.
A general-purpose, developmental, modeling language in the field of software engineering.

The power of UML is 'Abstraction'. You can show 10,000 lines of code in one 'Class Diagram'. This allows senior architects to find logic flaws or security holes in the design *before* those lines of code are ever written, saving massive amounts of refactoring time.
A super-organized way to draw pictures of how your code is built!

In 'Agile' environments, 'Heavy UML' is dead. We use 'Sketch-level' UML on whiteboards to communicate ideas quickly. We rarely document every single class in UML anymore because high-quality IDES can now 'Auto-generate' those diagrams from the code itself.
A standardized general-purpose modeling language in the field of software engineering that is intended to provide a standard way to visualize the design of a system.
A Use Case diagram is a drawing that shows 'Who' uses the app (Actors) and 'What' they do with it (circles), showing the relationship between them.

A Use Case diagram illustrates the functional requirements of a system. It identifies the actors (users/external systems) and the specific activities (use cases) they participate in. It defines the 'Scope' of the system from an external view.

Components include: Actors (Stick figures), Use Cases (Ovals), System Boundary (Box), and Associations (Lines). It also uses specialized relationships like `<<include>>` (mandatory sub-task) and `<<extend>>` (optional behavior).
Define 'Actor' and 'Use Case' and explain the differnece between an 'Include' and an 'Extend' relationship in a UML diagram.

It's like 'A Map of a Playground'. The stick figures are the kids. The ovals are the slide, the swing, and the sandbox. The lines show which kids are allowed to play on which toys. It doesn't show *how* they slide; it just shows that they *can* slide.
A behavioral UML diagram used to describe the set of actions that a system should perform in collaboration with external users.

Use Case diagrams are specifically for 'Communication'. They are simple enough for a CEO or a Customer to understand, but structured enough for a developer to use as a starting point for their coding plan. They explicitly define the 'Boundary' of what the software will and will NOT do.
A picture that shows all the people who will use your app and all the things they will do with it!

Misusing Use Case diagrams for UI design is a common error. A Use Case is a 'High-level goal' (e.g., 'Withdrawing Cash'), not a button click. One Use Case might actually be implemented by 10 different screens in the final product.
A representation of a user's interaction with the system that shows the relationship between the user and the different use cases in which the user is involved.

questions.question: What is 'Software Prototyping' in the context of requirements?

answer_variants.answer: In requirements, prototyping is building a quick 'Shell' of the app to show the user and ask: 'Is this what you meant?'. It's much easier to change a picture than it is to change 1,000 lines of code.

Prototyping in requirements is used for 'Requirement Validation'. By giving stakeholders an interactive model, you can identify missing features, misinterpreted needs, or impossible workflows long before the expensive coding phase begins.

Iterative prototyping reduces the 'Communication Gap'. It involves creating a 'Mockup' (static) or a 'Wireframe' (low-fidelity interactive), gathering feedback, and adjusting the SRS. This minimizes the risk of delivering a system that satisfies the specs but fails the user's needs.
What are the key benefits of using a prototype during the Requirements Elicitation phase?

It's like 'A Cardboard Model' of a house. You build it out of paper first. If the owner says 'The kitchen is too small', you just cut the paper and move it. You didn't waste any concrete (Code) or hours for the builders (Engineers).
An early, tangible model of a system used to clarify and validate functional requirements.

The 'Spiral Model' used prototyping for risk management. If a requirement is 'The system must identify faces in 1 second', a developer builds a prototype with just the AI engine to see if that speed is even possible (Technical Feasibility) before building the whole login system around it.
Show your customer a rough sketch or a clicky model so they can tell you 'Yes' or 'No' early on!

Current trends see 'Rapid Prototyping' integrated with A/B testing. You release two different prototypes to small user groups and use data (analytics) to 'prove' which requirement is better, rather than just guessing during a meeting.
The process of creating a preliminary version of a software system to discover and refine user requirements through experimentation.
Requirement traceability is a 'Map' or table that links every user request to the code that builds it and the test that checks it. It makes sure nothing gets forgotten.

Requirement Traceability is the ability to follow a requirement from its origin (the user request), through the design and code, to the final test case. We use a 'Requirement Traceability Matrix' (RTM) to ensure 100% project coverage.

Traceability links requirements to technical artifacts. It allows for 'Impact Analysis': if a requirement changes, you can instantly see which lines of code and which test scripts need to be updated, preventing hidden regressions.
Explain the concept of a 'Forward' and 'Backward' traceability matrix.

It's like 'Labeling every piece of a LEGO set'. If the instructions say 'Use a red block', and you have 50 red blocks, you want to know exactly which one goes into the engine. If you lose one, you can trace it back to the manual to see why the car isn't moving.
The relationship between requirements, development artifacts, and testing to ensure all needs are met.

Traceability is a legal requirement for many systems. If an airplane crashes, investigators use a traceability matrix to prove that the 'Auto-pilot turn' requirement was accurately designed, correctly coded, and successfully passed all safety tests before the plane took off.
A checklist that proves you did everything you promised to do!

Automated Traceability uses 'Git Hub' links. When a developer writes code, they tag the requirement ID (e.g., `#REQ-101`) in their commit message. This creates a digital 'thread' automatically, making the project much easier to audit without manual paperwork.
The ability to describe and follow the life of a requirement, in both a forwards and backwards direction, from its inception, through its development and specification, to its subsequent deployment.
